com.itko.lisa.test

Class DataSetImpl

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.itko.lisa.coordinator.LisaServerObjectImpl
      • com.itko.lisa.test.DataSetImpl
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    com.itko.lisa.net.LisaServerObject, DataSet, NamedType, com.itko.lisa.test.NameGenerator

    public abstract class DataSetImpl
extends com.itko.lisa.coordinator.LisaServerObjectImpl
implements DataSet, com.itko.lisa.net.LisaServerObject, com.itko.lisa.test.NameGenerator
    This is an abstract class that provides most of the context support for LISA Data Sets. It implements the DataSet interface and will run automagically as an RMI remotable object due to the fact that we will often need to distribute the client instances to other machines but will still want all those concurrently running clients to use one data set.

    This class is abstract because it does not provide the actual data set implementations, they are in its derived classes. As of this writing, many are available: delimited file, JDBC, and a counting set, for example.

    See Also:
    for a discussion of each method and the overall approach taken to data sets

      • NUMERIC

        protected static final java.lang.String NUMERIC
        Added for backward compatibility. In March 2013, for LISA 7.0, we renamed the type to "Numeric" (should have stayed "Number"). We're correcting this now, but need to support tests using either format. But, we don't want both to show up in the UI so one is the enum and the other txt.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

        This method is called to setup the properties of every data set. It is implemented by DataSetImpl since it should be common to every use. This method will call down into the initialize() method of the data set to do any polymorphic initialization that is needed.

        protected void loadFileAsBundled(java.lang.String location)
                          throws java.io.IOException
        This is how I will load into a buffer the contents of your file. You get an inputstream to use it later by called openBundledStream() and if you don't need the buffer afterward you can call clearBundledBuffer()

        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if there's a problem

      • collectDataSetElements

        public static java.util.Map<java.lang.String,org.w3c.dom.Element> collectDataSetElements(org.w3c.dom.Element testCaseNode)
        Returns a map of the DOM elements of each DataSet tag in the test case. The map's key is the data set's name (e.g., "DataSet1"). This method gets used to enable LISA to validate test cases during a save: we want to prevent users from saving test cases containing invalid data sets.
        Parameters:
        testCaseNode - the DOM element of the TestCase tag
        Returns:
        a map of the DOM elements of the DataSets within the test case

      • verifyDataSets

        public static void verifyDataSets(org.w3c.dom.Element docRoot,
                  java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> props)
                           throws TestDefException
        Verify data sets are well-defined. Any required fields of the data set must be provided before the test case can be saved. Test cases are prepared for staging when opened (see the TestCaseInfo::initFromScratchTestCase method, which calls prepareToStage). Without validating data sets during a save, users can save invalid test cases but then cannot reopen them. This check enables us to warn users a data set is invalid. This method returns when the first invalid data set is encountered. If a test case contains multiple invalid data sets, only the first one is reported. This method is nearly identical to the dataSetFactory method of this class. The difference is, dataSetFactory stages the data set.
        Parameters:
        docRoot - the DOM element of the TestCase tag
        props - runtime properties (this is where this method finds LISA_RELATIVE_PROJ_ROOT)
        Throws:
        TestDefException - if the data set is invalid
